questions.question_text: During a monthly vulnerability scan, a server was flagged for being vulnerable to an Apache Struts exploit. Upon further investigation, the developer responsible for the server informs the security team that Apache Struts is not installed on the server. Which of the following BEST describes how the security team should reach to this incident?

discussion.content: Answer is A. It was a vulnerablity scan. The server was flagged for being vulernable TO an Apache Struts exploit. The developer that was responsible for THAT server informs Security it is NOT installed. The vulnerabiltiy is not there. The scan was a false positive (meaning it detected something that really wasn't there).

comments.content: LOL! these discussions are top tier info and comedy , gotta love it

discussion.content: What EVER you do, do not listen to day95! In fact, I would put an implict DENY on all his/her opinions... wth does he mean "initial server doesnt have apache"? The damn developer said it dont have the "STRUTS" module...JEEZ

Unfortunately, vulnerability scanners aren’t perfect. Occasionally, they report a vulnerability when it doesn’t actually exist. In other words, the scan indicates a system has a known vulnerability, but the report is false. As an example, a vulnerability scan on a server might report that the server is missing patches related to a database application, but the server doesn’t have a database application installed (Darril Gibson’s Get Certified Get Ahead p. 574).

We have to first question the vulnerability scan that was done, then verify if Apache was truly installed or not then before we decide to quarantine. In a real-life scenario, this would have been the case. Option A is not a good step to take at all and option D alike. So in a sense, for best practice regarding security intelligence, eliminating all options presented, I'd go for option D with caution 'cos you don't neglect a security issue.
It is a false positive as vulnerability scans can cause many false positives as per the "get certified get ahead". you can use credentialed scans to reduce false positives.
Answer is D. If you're sure that on the server Apache is not installed, and with a scan you find "Apache is not updated" well... that's a problem.

Agree that answer is A. An exploit is moot if the designated target does not have any means for the potential exploit to function in the first place, and would be a waste of time and resources to address a potential threat if the threat has no means to take advantage of required vulnerability.

comments.content: Why would you dig deeper into a problem that doesn't exist?

discussion.content: The answer is not A, it is D because initially the server did not have apache, so malware infected the server and is referencing apache somehow. If the server did have apache initially, it would be a false positive if an anaylst went deeper into the problem and found nothing.
The answer is A false positive

choices.B: The Struts module needs to be hardened on the server
choices.C: The Apache software on the server needs to be patched and updated
choices.A: The finding is a false positive and can be disregarded
choices.D: The server has been compromised by malware and needs to be quarantined.

comments.content: I was thinking the same thing. I believe the answer is A & B

discussion.content: Shouldn't this be A and B? Remote wipe makes more sense since containerization means separating work from personal data. However, this device is strictly used for work-tasks, and no mention of personal use. So, what is the point of containerization?

Agreed that it's A and B. This might be another example of having to read the question very carefully. Here's how I read it: These devices are already on use as stated, and it's also stated that there's a container holding the data they want wiped, so containerization is already done. They only need to add A and B.
I absolutely hate comptia and their wording. A and B should work since it wants to delete the data on the device but I understand how it can be containerization its just terrible wording
A and B. Geofencing to identify when the device leaves, and remote wipe to destroy it when it does. Don't be fooled.

Containerization can also be implemented in mobile devices. By
running an application in a container, it isolates and protects the
application, including any of its data. This is very useful when an
organization allows employees to use their own devices. It’s possible
to encrypt the container to protect it without encrypting the entire
device.

Ref: Get Certified Get Ahead. p461
clearly A and B

questions.question_text: A systems administrator wants to protect data stored on mobile devices that are used to scan and record assets in a warehouse. The control must automatically destroy the secure container of mobile devices if they leave the warehouse. Which of the following should the administrator implement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
It is simple
1)SLE=AV(asset value) x EF(exposure Factor)
This just to see how much cost a company incur from at anytime an incident happens.
2)ALE= SLE X ROI meaning what will be the annual cost which is sinlge loss of an event times rate of occurrence (how frequently the incident occur in a given time) 
So the question is asking what is sinlge loss of an event that is SLE= AV x EF

comments.content: ALE is SLE x ARO, not ROI. Annual rate of occurrence, not return of investment.
Im taking the exam Saturday and im screwed

discussion.content: wrong. correct a and c

I'll go with provided answer.
Quantitative risk assessment aims to assign concrete values to each risk factor.
Single Loss Expectancy (SLE)—The amount that would be lost in a single occurrence of the risk factor. This is determined by multiplying the value of the asset by an Exposure Factor (EF). EF is the percentage of the asset value that would be lost.
Annual Loss Expectancy (ALE)—The amount that would be lost over the course of a year. This is determined by multiplying the SLE by the Annual Rate of Occurrence (ARO).

Thank fonka....
ALE and ARO, the answers is wrong.
A & C.
.......blurb

questions.question_text: A security analyst is performing a quantitative risk analysis. The risk analysis should show the potential monetary loss each time a threat or event occurs. Given this requirement, which of the following concepts would assist the analyst in determining this value? (Choose two.)
Which of the following AES modes of operation provide authentication? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
WPA2—CCMP—strongest wireless encryption—uses AES
AES supports all the modes listed under DES, but tends to use the much lower latency mode called Galois/Counter Mode (GCM)

choices.D: Implement regular permission auditing and reviews.
choices.A: Implement separation of duties for the payroll department.
choices.C: Implement rule-based access controls on the human resources server.
choices.B: Implement a DLP solution on the payroll and human resources servers.

discussion.content: Answer is D on the Actual Test
I really think it is D, since the audit found this after people changed jobs. separation of duties without permission and audit reviews would result in the same problem again as people change roles.
Prevent problems arising in an audit by having an audit lol ok
The best way to prevent similar audit findings in the future is to schedule more audits?

Yes D is correct because, it will stay on track and it will be great for security purposes for managers of the company to see and review the permissions of the accounts and permissions of terminated employees.

Possibly left the "Choose Two" part of question out? I saw that in Network+, we were arguing about a single answer, then it hits on my exam and was "Choose Two"...meanwhile this place, PassCompTia.com and BriefMeNow.com ALL had the same misworded question!!
I don't see why it is A...answer should be D...regularly auditing will help see those problems
This has NOTHING to do with separation of duties. They have the wrong PERMISSIONS. This is basic account management. Regular permission auditing& reviews will sort it out. Answer is D.
D is the answer
Answer is D

i have seen a lott debate on answer D.. but answer A is correct. As per question auditing is done he have already found terminated acoout.. now he has to
 delete that account. but the terminated account has a access to data of sales manager and marketing manager as in question so next step will be separation od duties which implifies correct data access..

oh! I see - the current Sales Manager has 2 duties under "payroll", as well as the terminated employee, which leaves him as the sole owner of those "payroll" duties.
Yeah, sure, A works, but why not D, though?

what payroll department?
what are its current permissions?

Hi all, i’m new in IT. very confusing about many answers that people said there are wrong. i’m preparing to take Sec+ exam, should i trust 100% this site or not? what about if this question comes in my test, what’s the right answers finaly. Have you guys identified other wrong answers? please let me know, i will appreciate you advice. thanks
It's D.... whoever is in charge of the site needs to update the answers and give those who are studying accurate information.
Being a Sales Manager, why the hell Ann has payroll access and how would separation of duties help here? BS!!

In my personal opinion D is the answer. I see the debate going on but I am having trouble understanding why Separation of Duties has anything to do with this question. 

Separation of Duties - the separation by sharing of more than one individual in one single task is an internal control intended to prevent fraud and error. Wikipedia
So what does this have to do with the question?

Back to my answer D. You should do audits regularly, and especially if you have people change roles/get terminated.

I don't see how the implementation of separation of duties (moreover done just for the payroll department) would fix all the issues found in this audit.

I can see many problems here, than just the one in the payroll department; we have people who may have TOO MANY privileges, people who may have WRONG permissions and people who SHOULD NOT HAVE ANY permission at all because maybe thay do not work for the company anymore (while they still have an active account).
Strictly speaking none of the given answer would really "PREVENT similar audit findings in the future"; anyway the best answer seems to be to implement REGULAR permission auditing and reviews (answer D).

The point here is that in this particular audit we found A LOT of problems; that means that probably the company hadn't done any audit in a long time; if we implement REGULAR audits (that means we do that FREQUENTLY), and of course we fix the problems found after each audit, after a while we'll reduce the probability to find so many issues all together in a single audit (so, in a way, we PREVENT such results from happening again in future).

None of the answers are correct lol. To prevent such findings in the future, do what? Prevent privilege creep and have least privilege. Best answer seems to be D. How would separation of duties prevent privilege creep ...

pt1: first duties will be defined.
pt2: and afterwards auditing will be done for the defined duties.
A, I believed, but another test has D.

First of all, D is not going to prevent the findings in the future. D would be a corrective measure and not a preventive.
Second, Ann is the new Sales Manager and John is the old one. Comparing the access that John had and what Ann has right now. Ann is has too much permissions

>>>The audit is in regards to access of confidential data<<

Ann and John both are Sales managers and had access to Confidential payroll shares, in context to the question provided answer seems correct.

Separation of Duties

A. why does ann have access to payroll. why does john have access to human resources. these duties need to be separated. there is evidence that anything was fraudulent, they assumption is, they were doing these duties.
answer is D from other resources too
BEST method to prevent similar audit findings in the future - it means the audit findings will be the same in future and to prevent that you need separation of duties. Answer is A
a is what you would do to fix the issue in the now and d seems to be the answer to prevent this from happening in the future.
The right answer is D in other sources and it is also the only one that makes sense
only an audit D would be the BEST method to prevent similar audit findings in the future
D makes more sense
So, what is the right one?
Implement separation of duties of payroll department.

comments.content: This won't fix the issues with the other servers (Marketing and HR), and does not address the active account for the former staff person.

discussion.content:
A permission auditing and review process verifies that the principle of least privilege is 
 followed. This includes ensuring users can access only the resources they need to perform their job.

A separation of duties policy separates individual tasks of an overall function between different entities or different people, and helps deter fraud. For example, a single person shouldn’t be able to approve bills and pay them, or print checks and then sign them.

So wouldn't a permission audit discover that John's account is still active despite him being 
terminated, and wouldn't it also discover that Ann has access to payroll shares and a payroll processing program? It seems to me that after a permission audit has occurred, you can then separate the duties of Ann and shut down John's account. The answer should be D.
why not c. d is not helping until corrective steps are taken.
John has been terminated but his account is still active. It seems like D should be the correct answer.
Shouldn't it be D to implement regular auditing and reviews? It is more than just a problem with the payroll access.
